channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: An American Ambassador Who Plunged Into Arab Life
item.description: J. Christopher Stevens, who was killed at a diplomatic mission in Libya, had an affection for Arab culture and street life made him many friends and contacts.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Dilan Samo, 13, attended a vigil outside Libya’s Consulate in New York on Thursday for J. Christopher Stevens, the United States ambassador who died in Libya.

item.title: U.S. Is Preparing for a Long Siege of Arab Unrest
item.description: The White House is girding itself for an extended period of turmoil that will test the security of American diplomatic missions and President Obama’s ability to shape the forces of change in the Arab world.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: A representation of the American flag was burned amid a protest in Hyderabad, India, on Friday.

item.title: Myanmar Activist Says He’s Canceling Trip to U.S.
item.description: A prominent activist is canceling a trip to the United States to receive a democracy award, to show solidarity with colleagues whose passports have apparently been denied.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: European Bank Overhaul Meets Opposition From Finance Ministers
item.description: A plan by the European Union to overhaul bank supervision and help troubled lenders hit a roadblock at a meeting of finance ministers.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Xi Jinping Returns Amid Tumult in China
item.description: Xi Jinping reappeared on Saturday as diplomatic tensions boiled over, with hundreds of demonstrators throwing rocks and eggs at the Japanese Embassy in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Chinese demonstrators clash with policemen at the barricades during an anti-Japan protests outside the Japanese Embassy in Beijing on Saturday.

item.title: Berlusconi’s Magazine Chi to Publish Topless Duchess Photos
item.description: The images of Kate Middleton sunbathing topless first appeared in the French magazine Closer, which is also owned by former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s Mondadori group.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO

item.title: Pope Benedict XVI, in Lebanon, Makes Plea for Religious Freedom
item.description: Pope Benedict XVI, speaking in Lebanon amid a wave of violence across the Muslim world, said religious freedom was fundamental to stability.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Pope Benedict XVI meeting on Saturday with religious authorities in Mount Lebanon.

item.title: South Africa Raids Homes for Weapons of Miners
item.description: Police officers swarmed the living quarters of workers at a platinum mine, searching for illegal weapons as part of a new government push to end a series of violent strikes.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: A man is arrested by police at Lonmin's Marikana mine in South Africa's North West Province on Saturday.

item.title: Scandal Bares Corruption Hampering India’s Growth
item.description: A brazen brand of crony capitalism has created huge fortunes for a few, at the expense of the nation as a whole, which is falling short in energy infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: By VIKAS BAJAJ and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: At a coal market in Mumbai, India. Natural resources remain tightly controlled by politicians and bureaucrats.

item.title: Anti-Putin Protesters March in Moscow
item.description: Russia’s opposition hoped to show that its ranks were unfazed by a battery of restrictions or the two-year prison sentences handed down to members of the punk rock band Pussy Riot.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters streamed down a Moscow street on Saturday with balloons representing the opposition punk group Pussy Riot.

item.title: Man Linked to Film in Protests Is Questioned
item.description: Nakoula Basseley Nakoula, one of the men behind the anti-Muslim film trailer that has sparked violent protests, was taken in for questioning by federal probation officers.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By IAN LOVETT
item.media:description: Nakoula Basseley Nakoula was questioned at the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s station in Cerritos.

item.title: Attack by Fringe Group Highlights the Problem of Libya Militias
item.description: Ansar al-Sharia, the brigade of rebel fighters that witnesses say led the attack on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi, holds that democracy is incompatible with Islam.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK, SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Hani al-Mansouri, a spokesman for Ansar al-Sharia, spoke Thursday about the Benghazi attack.

item.title: Young Afghan Lives, Lost in the Fog of War
item.description: Indiscriminate suicide bombings are robbing Afghanistan’s children of their dreams.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bibi Hawa with daughters Behishta, 5, left, and Mursal, 7, and a son, Faisal, 6, at home in Kabul. Ms. Hawa lost two daughters, Khorshid, 15, and Parwana, 11, in a suicide bombing on Sept. 8.

item.title: In Egypt, Security Forces Make Arrests in Tahrir Square
item.description: Egyptian security forces, under intense pressure from the United States, arrested scores of protesters on Saturday as anti-American protests seemed to subside across the region.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MARC SANTORA
item.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police officers in Tahrir Square in Cairo early Saturday, after clearing the area of protesters.

item.title: Afghans Act to Fill Top Security Posts
item.description: Afghan lawmakers approved all three of the president’s nominees for the government’s top security jobs on Saturday, avoiding a prolonged power vacuum.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Body Builders: Scientists Make Progress in Tailor-Made Organs
item.description: Tissue engineers have succeeded in making artificial organs that use a patient’s cells to become a living part of the body. Some hope to eventually prod the body to regenerate organs itself.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN
item.media:description: At the Karolinska Institute in Sweden, rat hearts and lungs are washed of living cells to reveal the extracellular structure.

item.title: Thousands Protest Austerity Measures in Spain and Portugal
item.description: People from all over Spain rallied in the capital on Saturday against punishing austerity measures imposed by the government in response to the financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Spanish workers march as they demonstrate against the government's austerity measures on Saturday.

item.title: Economic View: World Hunger, the Problem Left Behind - Economic View
item.description: Economic gains in many sectors have yet to solve the problem of feeding the world. In Africa alone, government policies and fertilizer costs are inhibiting agricultural progress.
item.dc:creator: By TYLER COWEN

item.title: U.N. Envoy Brahimi Meets President Assad in Syria
item.description: Lakhdar Brahimi, the special envoy representing the United Nations and the Arab League, said President Bashar al-Assad was “more aware than me of the scope and the seriousness of the crisis.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Photos of Topless Kate Middleton Prompt Lawsuit
item.description: Britain’s royal household rebuked a French magazine for photographs of the former Kate Middleton topless, evoking the furor around press coverage of Diana.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge in Malaysia on Friday.

item.title: Lia Lee, 1982-2012: Life Went On Around Her, Redefining Care by Bridging a Divide
item.description: The story of Lia Lee, the severely brain-damaged daughter of Hmong refugees, inspired a book that affected the way American medicine is practiced across cultures.
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX

item.title: A Leader in China Reappears in Public
item.description: Xi Jinping, who is expected to take over the Communist Party, was last seen in public on Sept. 1, raising questions about his health.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Pool Photo by How Hwee Young

item.title: The Saturday Profile: After Stint in New York, Banker Turns to Fashion in India
item.description: When an investment banker came back from the United States, she needed to remake her wardrobe. Now, she manages brand strategy for a leading Indian fashion house.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Anti-American Protests Over Film Expand to Nearly 20 Countries
item.description: Anti-American rage that began over a video insult to Islam spread to nearly 20 countries in the Middle East and beyond.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Protesters in front of the burning German Embassy in Khartoum, Sudan, after Friday Prayer.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Morocco Emerges as Key U.S. Ally in Troubled Region
item.description: In the face of the latest upsurge of anti-American feeling in the Middle East, the U.S. is short of reliable local allies. As Washington continues to wrestle with the consequences of the Arab Spring, Morocco has emerged as an island of stability in a sea of troubles.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
